claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination can sensitize tumors to anti-PD-L1 checkpoint blockade and improve control when combined.

evidence.quote: Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.
Preclinical arm: multiple murine tumor models with intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combinations.

claims.caveat: The human association is observational, and preclinical efficacy may not generalize to all human tumor settings.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination is associated with a broader antigenic landscape and greater immune-cell presence in tumors.

evidence.quote: Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination
Increased immune infiltration with combination therapy

claims.caveat: These quantitative readouts are summary values and mechanistic effects were not uniformly identical across all models.

claims.claim: Type I interferon signaling is a required mechanism in this sensitization process in the reported experiments.

evidence.quote: Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: Causality is best supported in mechanistic mouse experiments and has not been proven as the dominant driver clinically.

claims.claim: Retrospective human data suggest a survival advantage for vaccinated patients receiving immune checkpoint blockade.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment
The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

claims.caveat: Causal interpretation is limited by non-randomized design, variable vaccination timing, and heterogeneity in tumor types and treatment history.
